page.title: 14'Years of Change 'continued
page.content: During the last war Canadian Soldiers were billeted in the area particularly before the Normandy landings. A village clubhouse was opened in 1924, for the benefit of the villagers. Before the war a fisherman walked over the Downs from Brighton to sell his catch. Also travelling shops used to visit the village each week. Earl Haig planted a beech tree at the bottom of the hill. During the war a Radar Station was on the Downs outside the village. Telscombe still has no pub or shop. Every bank is planted with millions of Daffodil bulbs making the village a beautiful vision each spring. Around the village is the 'Tye' a piece of common land still used to graze sheep. There is little parking space in the narrow lane known as the 'High Street'
